trial_identification.studytitle: A study of a means to relieve pain for short term periods
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Manual Stimulation for Short-term Relief of Pain: A Randomized Controlled Trial in Patients with Pain seen in the Emergency Room, Renal, Dental and Oncology Clinics

conditions.healthcondition: Pain from diverse pathologies seen in the Emergency room, Renal, Dental and Oncology Clinics

interventions.interventions: Patients were randomly assigned to an active stimulation group, or a placebo stimulation group. Mild, non-invasive, and not injurious manual stimulation was applied to an area of the limbs' surface (the skin), while patients lay on a clinic bed.Thereafter, the patients arose to rate pain level by means of a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). To determine if the pain relief was durable, rating times varied from immediate to 60 minutes in various protocols. Patients in the Emergency Room test gave their evaluation, as soon as possible after the stimulation. The 10-min test protocol asked patients to determine pain relief at 0, 5 and 10 minutes, and the 60-min test protocol, at ten minutes intervals up to sixty minutes.
interventions.comparator: For the placebo stimulation, the manual stimulus was applied on the oppsite surface of the limbs, while patients lay on a clinic bed. Thereafter, the patients arose to rate pain level by means of a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Significant reduction of Visual Analogue Scale scores for the active stimulation relative to the placebo stimulation
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At time points up to 60 minutes (0, 5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 minutes).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pain from their respective pathologies when recruited for the tests.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Emotional instability, questionable metal status, younger than 15 years old, and, receipt of another analgesic within 12 hours of the test.

trial_design.concealment: The allocation of patients was performed in each test center under the direction of the primary investigator using the method of Random Permuted Blocks for numberical designation to a placebo or treatment group. The random number designations were placed in envelopes. Following study enrollment by clinic staff, each patient blindly drew one. Then, the doctor or his assistant applied the treatment ascribed to the number the patient drew. The patients were blinded to the intervention's atribute as placebo or therapy.
trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomization with allocation ratio one to one in varied block sizes.
trial_design.designfeatures: Patients were blind to the intervention as active treatment or placebo.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To determine whether the manipulation will or will not significantly relieve clinical pain, and the durability of that relief. The study hypothesis was that a brief manual stimulation correctly applied to specific areas of skin (based on Traditional Chinese Medicine) could relief pain.

contact.name: Jiman He
